userAgent: Mozilla/5.0 (Linux; Android 6.0.1; Nexus 5 Build/MRA58N) AppleWebKit/537.36(KHTML, like Gecko) Chrome/59.0.3033.0 Mobile Safari/537.36

is-on-https.name: is-on-https
is-on-https.helpText: All sites should be protected with HTTPS, even ones that don't handle sensitive data. HTTPS prevents intruders from tampering with or passively listening in on the communications between your app and your users, and is a prerequisite for HTTP/2 and many new web platform APIs. [Learn more](https://developers.google.com/web/tools/lighthouse/audits/https).

redirects-http.name: redirects-http
redirects-http.helpText: If you've already set up HTTPS, make sure that you redirect all HTTP traffic to HTTPS. [Learn more](https://developers.google.com/web/tools/lighthouse/audits/http-redirects-to-https).

service-worker.name: service-worker
service-worker.helpText: The service worker is the technology that enables your app to use many Progressive Web App features, such as offline, add to homescreen, and push notifications. [Learn more](https://developers.google.com/web/tools/lighthouse/audits/registered-service-worker).

works-offline.name: works-offline
works-offline.helpText: If you're building a Progressive Web App, consider using a service worker so that your app can work offline. [Learn more](https://developers.google.com/web/tools/lighthouse/audits/http-200-when-offline).

viewport.name: viewport
viewport.description: Has a `<meta name="viewport">` tag with `width` or `initial-scale`
viewport.helpText: Add a viewport meta tag to optimize your app for mobile screens. [Learn more](https://developers.google.com/web/tools/lighthouse/audits/has-viewport-meta-tag).

without-javascript.name: without-javascript
without-javascript.description: Contains some content when JavaScript is not available
without-javascript.helpText: Your app should display some content when JavaScript is disabled, even if it's just a warning to the user that JavaScript is required to use the app. [Learn more](https://developers.google.com/web/tools/lighthouse/audits/no-js).

first-meaningful-paint.name: first-meaningful-paint
first-meaningful-paint.helpText: First meaningful paint measures when the primary content of a page is visible. [Learn more](https://developers.google.com/web/tools/lighthouse/audits/first-meaningful-paint).

load-fast-enough-for-pwa.name: load-fast-enough-for-pwa
load-fast-enough-for-pwa.description: Page load is fast enough on 3G
load-fast-enough-for-pwa.helpText: Satisfied if the _Time To Interactive_ duration is shorter than _10 seconds_, as defined by the [PWA Baseline Checklist](https://developers.google.com/web/progressive-web-apps/checklist). Network throttling is required (specifically: RTT latencies >= 150 RTT are expected).

speed-index-metric.name: speed-index-metric
speed-index-metric.helpText: Speed Index shows how quickly the contents of a page are visibly populated. [Learn more](https://developers.google.com/web/tools/lighthouse/audits/speed-index).

estimated-input-latency.name: estimated-input-latency
estimated-input-latency.helpText: The score above is an estimate of how long your app takes to respond to user input, in milliseconds. There is a 90% probability that a user encounters this amount of latency, or less. 10% of the time a user can expect additional latency. If your score is higher than Lighthouse's target score, users may perceive your app as laggy. [Learn more](https://developers.google.com/web/tools/lighthouse/audits/estimated-input-latency).

time-to-interactive.name: time-to-interactive
time-to-interactive.helpText: Time to Interactive identifies the time at which your app appears to be ready enough to interact with. [Learn more](https://developers.google.com/web/tools/lighthouse/audits/time-to-interactive).

user-timings.name: user-timings
user-timings.helpText: Consider instrumenting your app with the User Timing API to create custom, real-world measurements of key user experiences. [Learn more](https://developers.google.com/web/tools/lighthouse/audits/user-timing).

critical-request-chains.name: critical-request-chains
critical-request-chains.helpText: The Critical Request Chains below show you what resources are required for first render of this page. Improve page load by reducing the length of chains, reducing the download size of resources, or deferring the download of unnecessary resources. [Learn more](https://developers.google.com/web/tools/lighthouse/audits/critical-request-chains).

webapp-install-banner.debugString: Failures: No manifest was fetched, Site registers a Service Worker.
webapp-install-banner.name: webapp-install-banner
webapp-install-banner.description: User can be prompted to Install the Web App
webapp-install-banner.helpText: While users can manually add your site to their homescreen, the [prompt (aka app install banner)](https://developers.google.com/web/fundamentals/engage-and-retain/app-install-banners/) will proactively prompt the user to install the app if the various requirements are met and the user has moderate engagement with your site.

splash-screen.name: splash-screen
splash-screen.description: Configured for a custom splash screen
splash-screen.helpText: A default splash screen will be constructed for your app, but satisfying these requirements guarantee a high-quality [splash screen](https://developers.google.com/web/updates/2015/10/splashscreen) that transitions the user from tapping the home screen icon to your app's first paint

themed-omnibox.debugString: Failures: No manifest was fetched, No `<meta name="theme-color">` tag found.
themed-omnibox.name: themed-omnibox
themed-omnibox.helpText: The browser address bar can be themed to match your site. A `theme-color` [meta tag](https://developers.google.com/web/updates/2014/11/Support-for-theme-color-in-Chrome-39-for-Android) will upgrade the address bar when a user browses the site, and the [manifest theme-color](https://developers.google.com/web/updates/2015/08/using-manifest-to-set-sitewide-theme-color) will apply the same theme site-wide once it's been added to homescreen.

manifest-short-name-length.name: manifest-short-name-length
manifest-short-name-length.description: Manifest's `short_name` won't be truncated when displayed on homescreen
manifest-short-name-length.helpText: Make your app's `short_name` less than 12 characters to ensure that it's not truncated on homescreens. [Learn more](https://developers.google.com/web/tools/lighthouse/audits/manifest-short_name-is-not-truncated).

content-width.name: content-width
content-width.description: Content is sized correctly for the viewport
content-width.helpText: If the width of your app's content doesn't match the width of the viewport, your app might not be optimized for mobile screens. [Learn more](https://developers.google.com/web/tools/lighthouse/audits/content-sized-correctly-for-viewport).

value.label: line: 45
value.code: Calling Element.createShadowRoot() for an element which already hosts a shadow root is deprecated. See https://www.chromestatus.com/features/4668884095336448 for more details.
value.text: Calling Element.createShadowRoot() for an element which already hosts a shadow root is deprecated. See https://www.chromestatus.com/features/4668884095336448 for more details.

value.label: line: 291
value.code: Synchronous XMLHttpRequest on the main thread is deprecated because of its detrimental effects to the end user's experience. For more help, check https://xhr.spec.whatwg.org/.
value.text: Synchronous XMLHttpRequest on the main thread is deprecated because of its detrimental effects to the end user's experience. For more help, check https://xhr.spec.whatwg.org/.

value.label: line: 294
value.code: 'window.webkitStorageInfo' is deprecated. Please use 'navigator.webkitTemporaryStorage' or 'navigator.webkitPersistentStorage' instead.
value.text: 'window.webkitStorageInfo' is deprecated. Please use 'navigator.webkitTemporaryStorage' or 'navigator.webkitPersistentStorage' instead.

value.label: line: ???
value.code: /deep/ combinator is deprecated and will be a no-op in M60, around August 2017. See https://www.chromestatus.com/features/4964279606312960 for more details.
value.text: /deep/ combinator is deprecated and will be a no-op in M60, around August 2017. See https://www.chromestatus.com/features/4964279606312960 for more details.

deprecations.name: deprecations
deprecations.helpText: Deprecated APIs will eventually be removed from the browser. [Learn more](https://www.chromestatus.com/features#deprecated).

accesskeys.name: accesskeys
accesskeys.helpText: `accesskey` attributes allow the user to quickly activate or focus part of the page.Using the same `accesskey` more than once could lead to a confusing experience.

aria-allowed-attr.name: aria-allowed-attr
aria-allowed-attr.helpText: Each ARIA `role` supports a specific subset of `aria-*` attributes. Mismatching these invalidates the `aria-*` attributes. [Learn more](https://developers.google.com/web/tools/lighthouse/audits/aria-allowed-attributes).

aria-required-attr.name: aria-required-attr
aria-required-attr.helpText: Some ARIA roles have required attributes that describe the state of the element to screen readers. [Learn more](https://developers.google.com/web/tools/lighthouse/audits/required-aria-attributes).

aria-required-children.name: aria-required-children
aria-required-children.helpText: Some ARIA parent roles require specific roles on their children to perform their accessibility function.

aria-required-parent.name: aria-required-parent
aria-required-parent.description: `[role]`s are contained by their required parent element.
aria-required-parent.helpText: Some ARIA roles require specific roles on their parent element to perform their accessibility function.

aria-roles.name: aria-roles
aria-roles.helpText: ARIA roles require specific values to perform their accessibility function.

aria-valid-attr-value.name: aria-valid-attr-value
aria-valid-attr-value.helpText: Assistive technologies, like screen readers, can't interpret ARIA attributes with invalid values. [Learn more](https://developers.google.com/web/tools/lighthouse/audits/valid-aria-values).

aria-valid-attr.name: aria-valid-attr
aria-valid-attr.description: `[aria-*]` attributes are valid and not misspelled.
aria-valid-attr.helpText: Assistive technologies, like screen readers, can't interpret ARIA attributes with invalid names. [Learn more](https://developers.google.com/web/tools/lighthouse/audits/valid-aria-attributes).

audio-caption.name: audio-caption
audio-caption.helpText: Captions convey information such as identifying who is speaking, dialogue, and non-speech information. This can help deaf or hearing impaired users access meaningful content.

button-name.name: button-name
button-name.helpText: An accessible name helps convey the purpose of a button. Without one, a screen reader will only announce the word "button".

bypass.name: bypass
bypass.description: The page contains a heading, skip link, or landmark region.
bypass.helpText: Adding ways to bypass repetitive content lets keyboard users navigate the page more efficiently.

value.description: Ensures the contrast between foreground and background colors meets WCAG 2 AA contrast ratio thresholds
value.help: Elements must have sufficient color contrast

any.message: Element has insufficient color contrast of 1.33 (foreground color: #ffc0cb, background color: #eeeeee, font size: 18.0pt, font weight: bold)

nodes.failureSummary:
Fix any of the following:
  Element has insufficient color contrast of 1.33 (foreground color: #ffc0cb, background color: #eeeeee, font size: 18.0pt, font weight: bold)

any.message: Element has insufficient color contrast of 1.33 (foreground color: #ffc0cb, background color: #eeeeee, font size: 12.0pt, font weight: normal)

nodes.failureSummary:
Fix any of the following:
  Element has insufficient color contrast of 1.33 (foreground color: #ffc0cb, background color: #eeeeee, font size: 12.0pt, font weight: normal)

color-contrast.name: color-contrast
color-contrast.description: Background and foreground colors have a sufficient contrast ratio.
color-contrast.helpText: Low-contrast text is difficult or impossible for many users to read. [Learn more](https://developers.google.com/web/tools/lighthouse/audits/contrast-ratio).

definition-list.name: definition-list
definition-list.description: `<dl>`'s contain only properly-ordered `<dt>` and `<dd>` groups, `<script>` or <template> elements.
definition-list.helpText: When definition lists are not properly marked up screen readers may produce confusing or inaccurate output.

dlitem.name: dlitem
dlitem.description: Definition list items are wrapped in `<dl>` elements.
dlitem.helpText: Definition list items (<dt> and/or <dd>) wrapped in parent <dl> elements enable screen readers to properly announce content.

document-title.name: document-title
document-title.helpText: Screen reader users use page titles to get an overview of the contents of the page.

duplicate-id.name: duplicate-id
duplicate-id.description: `[id]` attributes on the page are unique.
duplicate-id.helpText: Unique `id=""` attributes help ensure assistive technologies do not overlook elements with the same id.

frame-title.name: frame-title
frame-title.helpText: Screen reader users rely on a frame title to describe the contents of the frame.

value.description: Ensures every HTML document has a lang attribute
value.help: <html> element must have a lang attribute

any.message: The <html> element does not have a lang attribute

nodes.failureSummary:
Fix any of the following:
  The <html> element does not have a lang attribute

html-has-lang.name: html-has-lang
html-has-lang.helpText: The `lang` attribute is useful for multilingual screen reader users who may prefer a language other than the default.

html-lang-valid.name: html-lang-valid
html-lang-valid.description: `<html>` element has a valid value for its `[lang]` attribute.
html-lang-valid.helpText: Specifying a valid [BCP 47 language](https://www.w3.org/International/questions/qa-choosing-language-tags#question) helps screen readers announce text properly.

image-alt.name: image-alt
image-alt.helpText: Informative elements should aim for short, descriptive alternate text. Decorative elements can be ignored with an empty alt attributes, e.g. [alt=""].[Learn more](https://developers.google.com/web/tools/lighthouse/audits/alt-attribute).

input-image-alt.name: input-image-alt
input-image-alt.helpText: When an image is being used as an `<input>` button, providing alternative text can help screen reader users understand the purpose of the button.

label.name: label
label.helpText: Labels ensure that form controls are announced properly by assistive technologies, like screen readers. [Learn more](https://developers.google.com/web/tools/lighthouse/audits/form-labels).

layout-table.name: layout-table
layout-table.description: Presentational `<table>` elements avoid using `<th>`, `<caption>` or the `[summary]` attribute.
layout-table.helpText: The presence of `<th>`, `<caption>` or the `summary` attribute on a presentational table may produce a confusing experince for a screen reader user as these elements usually indicates a data table.

link-name.name: link-name
link-name.helpText: Link text (and alternate text for images, when used as links) that is discernible, not duplicated, and focusable improves the navigating experience for screen reader users.

list.name: list
list.description: Lists contain only `<li>` elements and script supporting elements (`<script>` and `<template>`).
list.helpText: Screen readers have a specific way of announcing lists. Ensuring proper list structure aides screen reader output.

listitem.name: listitem
listitem.description: List items (`<li>`) are contained within `<ul>` or `<ol>` parent elements.
listitem.helpText: Screen readers require list items (`<li>`) to be contained within a parent `<ul>` or `<ol>` to be announced properly

meta-refresh.name: meta-refresh
meta-refresh.description: The document does not use `<meta http-equiv="refresh">`.
meta-refresh.helpText: Users do not expect a page to refresh automatically, and doing so will move focus back to the top of the page. This may create a frustrating or confusing experience

meta-viewport.name: meta-viewport
meta-viewport.description: `[user-scalable="no"]` is not used in the `<meta name="viewport">` element and the `[maximum-scale]` attribute is not less than 5.
meta-viewport.helpText: Disabling zooming is problematic for users with low vision who rely on screen magnification to properly see the contents of a web page.

object-alt.name: object-alt
object-alt.helpText: Screen readers cannot translate non-text content. Adding alt text to `<object>` elements will help a screen reader convey the meaning to a user.

tabindex.name: tabindex
tabindex.description: No element has a `[tabindex]` value greater than 0.
tabindex.helpText: A value greater than 0 implies an explicit navigation ordering. Although technically valid, this often creates frustrating experiences for users who rely on assistive technologies. [Learn more](https://developers.google.com/web/tools/lighthouse/audits/tabindex).

td-headers-attr.name: td-headers-attr
td-headers-attr.description: Cells in a `<table>` element that use the `[headers]` attribute only refer to other cells of that same table.
td-headers-attr.helpText: Screen readers have features to make navigating tables easier. Ensuring `<td>` cells using the `[headers]` attribute only refer to other cells in the same table may improve the experience for screen reader users.

th-has-data-cells.name: th-has-data-cells
th-has-data-cells.description: `<th>` elements and elements with `[role="columnheader"/"rowheader"]` have data cells they describe.
th-has-data-cells.helpText: Screen readers have features to make navigating tables easier. Ensuring table headers always refer to some set of cells may improve the experience for screen reader users.

valid-lang.name: valid-lang
valid-lang.helpText: Specifying a valid [BCP 47 language](https://www.w3.org/International/questions/qa-choosing-language-tags#question) on elements helps ensure that text is pronounced correctly by a screen reader.

video-caption.name: video-caption
video-caption.helpText: When a video provides a caption it is easier for deaf and hearing impaired users to access its information.

video-description.name: video-description
video-description.helpText: Audio descriptions provide relevant information for videos that dialogue cannot, such as facial expressions and scenes.

total-byte-weight.name: total-byte-weight
total-byte-weight.helpText: Network transfer size [costs users real dollars](https://whatdoesmysitecost.com/) and is [highly correlated](http://httparchive.org/interesting.php#onLoad) with long load times. Try to find ways to reduce the size of required files.

offscreen-images.name: offscreen-images
offscreen-images.helpText: Images that are not above the fold should be lazily loaded after the page is interactive. Consider using the [IntersectionObserver](https://developers.google.com/web/updates/2016/04/intersectionobserver) API.

uses-optimized-images.name: uses-optimized-images
uses-optimized-images.helpText: Images should be optimized to save network bytes. The following images could have smaller file sizes when compressed with [WebP](https://developers.google.com/speed/webp/) or JPEG at 80 quality. [Learn more about image optimization](https://developers.google.com/web/fundamentals/performance/optimizing-content-efficiency/image-optimization).

uses-request-compression.name: uses-request-compression
uses-request-compression.helpText: Text-based responses should be served with compression (gzip, deflate or brotli) to minimize total network bytes. [Learn more](https://developers.google.com/web/fundamentals/performance/optimizing-content-efficiency/optimize-encoding-and-transfer).

uses-responsive-images.name: uses-responsive-images
uses-responsive-images.helpText: Image sizes served should be based on the device display size to save network bytes. Learn more about [responsive images](https://developers.google.com/web/fundamentals/design-and-ui/media/images) and [client hints](https://developers.google.com/web/updates/2015/09/automating-resource-selection-with-client-hints).

appcache-manifest.name: appcache-manifest
appcache-manifest.helpText: Application Cache has been [deprecated](https://html.spec.whatwg.org/multipage/browsers.html#offline) by [Service Workers](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/Service_Worker_API/Using_Service_Workers). Consider implementing an offline solution using the [Cache Storage API](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/Cache).

dom-size.name: dom-size
dom-size.helpText: Browser engineers recommend pages contain fewer than ~1,500 DOM nodes. The sweet spot is a tree depth < 32 elements and fewer than 60 children/parent element. A large DOM can increase memory, cause longer [style calculations](https://developers.google.com/web/fundamentals/performance/rendering/reduce-the-scope-and-complexity-of-style-calculations), and produce costly [layout reflows](https://developers.google.com/speed/articles/reflow). [Learn more](https://developers.google.com/web/fundamentals/performance/rendering/).

external-anchors-use-rel-noopener.debugString: Lighthouse was unable to determine the destination of some anchor tags. If they are not used as hyperlinks, consider removing the _blank target.
external-anchors-use-rel-noopener.name: external-anchors-use-rel-noopener
external-anchors-use-rel-noopener.helpText: Open new tabs using `rel="noopener"` to improve performance and prevent security vulnerabilities. [Learn more](https://developers.google.com/web/tools/lighthouse/audits/noopener).

geolocation-on-start.name: geolocation-on-start
geolocation-on-start.description: Avoids requesting the geolocation permission on page load
geolocation-on-start.helpText: Users are mistrustful of or confused by sites that request their location without context. Consider tying the request to user gestures instead. [Learn more](https://developers.google.com/web/tools/lighthouse/audits/geolocation-on-load).

link-blocking-first-paint.name: link-blocking-first-paint
link-blocking-first-paint.helpText: Link elements are blocking the first paint of your page. Consider inlining critical links and deferring non-critical ones. [Learn more](https://developers.google.com/web/tools/lighthouse/audits/blocking-resources).

no-console-time.name: no-console-time
no-console-time.helpText: Consider using `performance.mark()` and `performance.measure()` from the User Timing API instead. They provide high-precision timestamps, independent of the system clock, and are integrated in the Chrome DevTools Timeline. [Learn more](https://developers.google.com/web/tools/lighthouse/audits/console-time).

no-datenow.name: no-datenow
no-datenow.helpText: Consider using `performance.now()` from the User Timing API instead. It provides high-precision timestamps, independent of the system clock. [Learn more](https://developers.google.com/web/tools/lighthouse/audits/date-now).

no-document-write.name: no-document-write
no-document-write.helpText: For users on slow connections, external scripts dynamically injected via `document.write()` can delay page load by tens of seconds. [Learn more](https://developers.google.com/web/tools/lighthouse/audits/document-write).

no-mutation-events.name: no-mutation-events
no-mutation-events.description: Avoids Mutation Events in its own scripts
no-mutation-events.helpText: Mutation Events are deprecated and harm performance. Consider using Mutation Observers instead. [Learn more](https://developers.google.com/web/tools/lighthouse/audits/mutation-events).

no-old-flexbox.name: no-old-flexbox
no-old-flexbox.helpText: The 2009 spec of Flexbox is deprecated and is 2.3x slower than the latest spec. [Learn more](https://developers.google.com/web/tools/lighthouse/audits/old-flexbox).

no-websql.name: no-websql
no-websql.helpText: Web SQL is deprecated. Consider using IndexedDB instead. [Learn more](https://developers.google.com/web/tools/lighthouse/audits/web-sql).

notification-on-start.name: notification-on-start
notification-on-start.description: Avoids requesting the notification permission on page load
notification-on-start.helpText: Users are mistrustful of or confused by sites that request to send notifications without context. Consider tying the request to user gestures instead. [Learn more](https://developers.google.com/web/tools/lighthouse/audits/notifications-on-load).

script-blocking-first-paint.name: script-blocking-first-paint
script-blocking-first-paint.helpText: Script elements are blocking the first paint of your page. Consider inlining critical scripts and deferring non-critical ones. [Learn more](https://developers.google.com/web/tools/lighthouse/audits/blocking-resources).

uses-http2.displayValue: 12 requests were not handled over h2
uses-http2.name: uses-http2
uses-http2.description: Uses HTTP/2 for its own resources
uses-http2.helpText: HTTP/2 offers many benefits over HTTP/1.1, including binary headers, multiplexing, and server push. [Learn more](https://developers.google.com/web/tools/lighthouse/audits/http2).

uses-passive-event-listeners.name: uses-passive-event-listeners
uses-passive-event-listeners.description: Uses passive listeners to improve scrolling performance
uses-passive-event-listeners.helpText: Consider marking your touch and wheel event listeners as `passive` to improve your page's scroll performance. [Learn more](https://developers.google.com/web/tools/lighthouse/audits/passive-event-listeners).

reportCategories.name: Progressive Web App
reportCategories.description: These audits validate the aspects of a Progressive Web App. They are a subset of the [PWA Checklist](https://developers.google.com/web/progressive-web-apps/checklist).

result.name: service-worker
result.helpText: The service worker is the technology that enables your app to use many Progressive Web App features, such as offline, add to homescreen, and push notifications. [Learn more](https://developers.google.com/web/tools/lighthouse/audits/registered-service-worker).

result.name: works-offline
result.helpText: If you're building a Progressive Web App, consider using a service worker so that your app can work offline. [Learn more](https://developers.google.com/web/tools/lighthouse/audits/http-200-when-offline).

result.name: without-javascript
result.description: Contains some content when JavaScript is not available
result.helpText: Your app should display some content when JavaScript is disabled, even if it's just a warning to the user that JavaScript is required to use the app. [Learn more](https://developers.google.com/web/tools/lighthouse/audits/no-js).

result.name: is-on-https
result.helpText: All sites should be protected with HTTPS, even ones that don't handle sensitive data. HTTPS prevents intruders from tampering with or passively listening in on the communications between your app and your users, and is a prerequisite for HTTP/2 and many new web platform APIs. [Learn more](https://developers.google.com/web/tools/lighthouse/audits/https).

result.name: redirects-http
result.helpText: If you've already set up HTTPS, make sure that you redirect all HTTP traffic to HTTPS. [Learn more](https://developers.google.com/web/tools/lighthouse/audits/http-redirects-to-https).

result.name: load-fast-enough-for-pwa
result.description: Page load is fast enough on 3G
result.helpText: Satisfied if the _Time To Interactive_ duration is shorter than _10 seconds_, as defined by the [PWA Baseline Checklist](https://developers.google.com/web/progressive-web-apps/checklist). Network throttling is required (specifically: RTT latencies >= 150 RTT are expected).

result.debugString: Failures: No manifest was fetched, Site registers a Service Worker.
result.name: webapp-install-banner
result.description: User can be prompted to Install the Web App
result.helpText: While users can manually add your site to their homescreen, the [prompt (aka app install banner)](https://developers.google.com/web/fundamentals/engage-and-retain/app-install-banners/) will proactively prompt the user to install the app if the various requirements are met and the user has moderate engagement with your site.

result.name: splash-screen
result.description: Configured for a custom splash screen
result.helpText: A default splash screen will be constructed for your app, but satisfying these requirements guarantee a high-quality [splash screen](https://developers.google.com/web/updates/2015/10/splashscreen) that transitions the user from tapping the home screen icon to your app's first paint

result.debugString: Failures: No manifest was fetched, No `<meta name="theme-color">` tag found.
result.name: themed-omnibox
result.helpText: The browser address bar can be themed to match your site. A `theme-color` [meta tag](https://developers.google.com/web/updates/2014/11/Support-for-theme-color-in-Chrome-39-for-Android) will upgrade the address bar when a user browses the site, and the [manifest theme-color](https://developers.google.com/web/updates/2015/08/using-manifest-to-set-sitewide-theme-color) will apply the same theme site-wide once it's been added to homescreen.

result.name: viewport
result.description: Has a `<meta name="viewport">` tag with `width` or `initial-scale`
result.helpText: Add a viewport meta tag to optimize your app for mobile screens. [Learn more](https://developers.google.com/web/tools/lighthouse/audits/has-viewport-meta-tag).

result.name: content-width
result.description: Content is sized correctly for the viewport
result.helpText: If the width of your app's content doesn't match the width of the viewport, your app might not be optimized for mobile screens. [Learn more](https://developers.google.com/web/tools/lighthouse/audits/content-sized-correctly-for-viewport).

result.name: first-meaningful-paint
result.helpText: First meaningful paint measures when the primary content of a page is visible. [Learn more](https://developers.google.com/web/tools/lighthouse/audits/first-meaningful-paint).

result.name: speed-index-metric
result.helpText: Speed Index shows how quickly the contents of a page are visibly populated. [Learn more](https://developers.google.com/web/tools/lighthouse/audits/speed-index).

result.name: estimated-input-latency
result.helpText: The score above is an estimate of how long your app takes to respond to user input, in milliseconds. There is a 90% probability that a user encounters this amount of latency, or less. 10% of the time a user can expect additional latency. If your score is higher than Lighthouse's target score, users may perceive your app as laggy. [Learn more](https://developers.google.com/web/tools/lighthouse/audits/estimated-input-latency).

result.name: time-to-interactive
result.helpText: Time to Interactive identifies the time at which your app appears to be ready enough to interact with. [Learn more](https://developers.google.com/web/tools/lighthouse/audits/time-to-interactive).

result.name: link-blocking-first-paint
result.helpText: Link elements are blocking the first paint of your page. Consider inlining critical links and deferring non-critical ones. [Learn more](https://developers.google.com/web/tools/lighthouse/audits/blocking-resources).

result.name: script-blocking-first-paint
result.helpText: Script elements are blocking the first paint of your page. Consider inlining critical scripts and deferring non-critical ones. [Learn more](https://developers.google.com/web/tools/lighthouse/audits/blocking-resources).

result.name: uses-optimized-images
result.helpText: Images should be optimized to save network bytes. The following images could have smaller file sizes when compressed with [WebP](https://developers.google.com/speed/webp/) or JPEG at 80 quality. [Learn more about image optimization](https://developers.google.com/web/fundamentals/performance/optimizing-content-efficiency/image-optimization).

result.name: uses-request-compression
result.helpText: Text-based responses should be served with compression (gzip, deflate or brotli) to minimize total network bytes. [Learn more](https://developers.google.com/web/fundamentals/performance/optimizing-content-efficiency/optimize-encoding-and-transfer).

result.name: uses-responsive-images
result.helpText: Image sizes served should be based on the device display size to save network bytes. Learn more about [responsive images](https://developers.google.com/web/fundamentals/design-and-ui/media/images) and [client hints](https://developers.google.com/web/updates/2015/09/automating-resource-selection-with-client-hints).

result.name: total-byte-weight
result.helpText: Network transfer size [costs users real dollars](https://whatdoesmysitecost.com/) and is [highly correlated](http://httparchive.org/interesting.php#onLoad) with long load times. Try to find ways to reduce the size of required files.

result.name: dom-size
result.helpText: Browser engineers recommend pages contain fewer than ~1,500 DOM nodes. The sweet spot is a tree depth < 32 elements and fewer than 60 children/parent element. A large DOM can increase memory, cause longer [style calculations](https://developers.google.com/web/fundamentals/performance/rendering/reduce-the-scope-and-complexity-of-style-calculations), and produce costly [layout reflows](https://developers.google.com/speed/articles/reflow). [Learn more](https://developers.google.com/web/fundamentals/performance/rendering/).

result.name: critical-request-chains
result.helpText: The Critical Request Chains below show you what resources are required for first render of this page. Improve page load by reducing the length of chains, reducing the download size of resources, or deferring the download of unnecessary resources. [Learn more](https://developers.google.com/web/tools/lighthouse/audits/critical-request-chains).

result.name: user-timings
result.helpText: Consider instrumenting your app with the User Timing API to create custom, real-world measurements of key user experiences. [Learn more](https://developers.google.com/web/tools/lighthouse/audits/user-timing).

reportCategories.name: Accessibility
reportCategories.description: These checks highlight opportunities to [improve the accessibility of your app](https://developers.google.com/web/fundamentals/accessibility).

result.name: accesskeys
result.helpText: `accesskey` attributes allow the user to quickly activate or focus part of the page.Using the same `accesskey` more than once could lead to a confusing experience.

result.name: aria-allowed-attr
result.helpText: Each ARIA `role` supports a specific subset of `aria-*` attributes. Mismatching these invalidates the `aria-*` attributes. [Learn more](https://developers.google.com/web/tools/lighthouse/audits/aria-allowed-attributes).

result.name: aria-required-attr
result.helpText: Some ARIA roles have required attributes that describe the state of the element to screen readers. [Learn more](https://developers.google.com/web/tools/lighthouse/audits/required-aria-attributes).

result.name: aria-required-children
result.helpText: Some ARIA parent roles require specific roles on their children to perform their accessibility function.

result.name: aria-required-parent
result.description: `[role]`s are contained by their required parent element.
result.helpText: Some ARIA roles require specific roles on their parent element to perform their accessibility function.

result.name: aria-roles
result.helpText: ARIA roles require specific values to perform their accessibility function.

result.name: aria-valid-attr-value
result.helpText: Assistive technologies, like screen readers, can't interpret ARIA attributes with invalid values. [Learn more](https://developers.google.com/web/tools/lighthouse/audits/valid-aria-values).

result.name: aria-valid-attr
result.description: `[aria-*]` attributes are valid and not misspelled.
result.helpText: Assistive technologies, like screen readers, can't interpret ARIA attributes with invalid names. [Learn more](https://developers.google.com/web/tools/lighthouse/audits/valid-aria-attributes).

result.name: audio-caption
result.helpText: Captions convey information such as identifying who is speaking, dialogue, and non-speech information. This can help deaf or hearing impaired users access meaningful content.

result.name: button-name
result.helpText: An accessible name helps convey the purpose of a button. Without one, a screen reader will only announce the word "button".

result.name: bypass
result.description: The page contains a heading, skip link, or landmark region.
result.helpText: Adding ways to bypass repetitive content lets keyboard users navigate the page more efficiently.

value.description: Ensures the contrast between foreground and background colors meets WCAG 2 AA contrast ratio thresholds
value.help: Elements must have sufficient color contrast

any.message: Element has insufficient color contrast of 1.33 (foreground color: #ffc0cb, background color: #eeeeee, font size: 18.0pt, font weight: bold)

nodes.failureSummary:
Fix any of the following:
  Element has insufficient color contrast of 1.33 (foreground color: #ffc0cb, background color: #eeeeee, font size: 18.0pt, font weight: bold)

any.message: Element has insufficient color contrast of 1.33 (foreground color: #ffc0cb, background color: #eeeeee, font size: 12.0pt, font weight: normal)

nodes.failureSummary:
Fix any of the following:
  Element has insufficient color contrast of 1.33 (foreground color: #ffc0cb, background color: #eeeeee, font size: 12.0pt, font weight: normal)

result.name: color-contrast
result.description: Background and foreground colors have a sufficient contrast ratio.
result.helpText: Low-contrast text is difficult or impossible for many users to read. [Learn more](https://developers.google.com/web/tools/lighthouse/audits/contrast-ratio).

result.name: definition-list
result.description: `<dl>`'s contain only properly-ordered `<dt>` and `<dd>` groups, `<script>` or <template> elements.
result.helpText: When definition lists are not properly marked up screen readers may produce confusing or inaccurate output.

result.name: dlitem
result.description: Definition list items are wrapped in `<dl>` elements.
result.helpText: Definition list items (<dt> and/or <dd>) wrapped in parent <dl> elements enable screen readers to properly announce content.

result.name: document-title
result.helpText: Screen reader users use page titles to get an overview of the contents of the page.

result.name: duplicate-id
result.description: `[id]` attributes on the page are unique.
result.helpText: Unique `id=""` attributes help ensure assistive technologies do not overlook elements with the same id.

result.name: frame-title
result.helpText: Screen reader users rely on a frame title to describe the contents of the frame.

value.description: Ensures every HTML document has a lang attribute
value.help: <html> element must have a lang attribute

any.message: The <html> element does not have a lang attribute

nodes.failureSummary:
Fix any of the following:
  The <html> element does not have a lang attribute

result.name: html-has-lang
result.helpText: The `lang` attribute is useful for multilingual screen reader users who may prefer a language other than the default.

result.name: html-lang-valid
result.description: `<html>` element has a valid value for its `[lang]` attribute.
result.helpText: Specifying a valid [BCP 47 language](https://www.w3.org/International/questions/qa-choosing-language-tags#question) helps screen readers announce text properly.

result.name: image-alt
result.helpText: Informative elements should aim for short, descriptive alternate text. Decorative elements can be ignored with an empty alt attributes, e.g. [alt=""].[Learn more](https://developers.google.com/web/tools/lighthouse/audits/alt-attribute).

result.name: input-image-alt
result.helpText: When an image is being used as an `<input>` button, providing alternative text can help screen reader users understand the purpose of the button.

result.name: label
result.helpText: Labels ensure that form controls are announced properly by assistive technologies, like screen readers. [Learn more](https://developers.google.com/web/tools/lighthouse/audits/form-labels).

result.name: layout-table
result.description: Presentational `<table>` elements avoid using `<th>`, `<caption>` or the `[summary]` attribute.
result.helpText: The presence of `<th>`, `<caption>` or the `summary` attribute on a presentational table may produce a confusing experince for a screen reader user as these elements usually indicates a data table.

result.name: link-name
result.helpText: Link text (and alternate text for images, when used as links) that is discernible, not duplicated, and focusable improves the navigating experience for screen reader users.

result.name: list
result.description: Lists contain only `<li>` elements and script supporting elements (`<script>` and `<template>`).
result.helpText: Screen readers have a specific way of announcing lists. Ensuring proper list structure aides screen reader output.

result.name: listitem
result.description: List items (`<li>`) are contained within `<ul>` or `<ol>` parent elements.
result.helpText: Screen readers require list items (`<li>`) to be contained within a parent `<ul>` or `<ol>` to be announced properly

result.name: meta-refresh
result.description: The document does not use `<meta http-equiv="refresh">`.
result.helpText: Users do not expect a page to refresh automatically, and doing so will move focus back to the top of the page. This may create a frustrating or confusing experience

result.name: meta-viewport
result.description: `[user-scalable="no"]` is not used in the `<meta name="viewport">` element and the `[maximum-scale]` attribute is not less than 5.
result.helpText: Disabling zooming is problematic for users with low vision who rely on screen magnification to properly see the contents of a web page.

result.name: object-alt
result.helpText: Screen readers cannot translate non-text content. Adding alt text to `<object>` elements will help a screen reader convey the meaning to a user.

result.name: tabindex
result.description: No element has a `[tabindex]` value greater than 0.
result.helpText: A value greater than 0 implies an explicit navigation ordering. Although technically valid, this often creates frustrating experiences for users who rely on assistive technologies. [Learn more](https://developers.google.com/web/tools/lighthouse/audits/tabindex).

result.name: td-headers-attr
result.description: Cells in a `<table>` element that use the `[headers]` attribute only refer to other cells of that same table.
result.helpText: Screen readers have features to make navigating tables easier. Ensuring `<td>` cells using the `[headers]` attribute only refer to other cells in the same table may improve the experience for screen reader users.

result.name: th-has-data-cells
result.description: `<th>` elements and elements with `[role="columnheader"/"rowheader"]` have data cells they describe.
result.helpText: Screen readers have features to make navigating tables easier. Ensuring table headers always refer to some set of cells may improve the experience for screen reader users.

result.name: valid-lang
result.helpText: Specifying a valid [BCP 47 language](https://www.w3.org/International/questions/qa-choosing-language-tags#question) on elements helps ensure that text is pronounced correctly by a screen reader.

result.name: video-caption
result.helpText: When a video provides a caption it is easier for deaf and hearing impaired users to access its information.

result.name: video-description
result.helpText: Audio descriptions provide relevant information for videos that dialogue cannot, such as facial expressions and scenes.

reportCategories.name: Best Practices
reportCategories.description: We've compiled some recommendations for modernizing your web app and avoiding performance pitfalls. These audits do not affect your score but are worth a look.

result.name: appcache-manifest
result.helpText: Application Cache has been [deprecated](https://html.spec.whatwg.org/multipage/browsers.html#offline) by [Service Workers](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/Service_Worker_API/Using_Service_Workers). Consider implementing an offline solution using the [Cache Storage API](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/Cache).

result.name: no-websql
result.helpText: Web SQL is deprecated. Consider using IndexedDB instead. [Learn more](https://developers.google.com/web/tools/lighthouse/audits/web-sql).

result.name: is-on-https
result.helpText: All sites should be protected with HTTPS, even ones that don't handle sensitive data. HTTPS prevents intruders from tampering with or passively listening in on the communications between your app and your users, and is a prerequisite for HTTP/2 and many new web platform APIs. [Learn more](https://developers.google.com/web/tools/lighthouse/audits/https).

result.displayValue: 12 requests were not handled over h2
result.name: uses-http2
result.description: Uses HTTP/2 for its own resources
result.helpText: HTTP/2 offers many benefits over HTTP/1.1, including binary headers, multiplexing, and server push. [Learn more](https://developers.google.com/web/tools/lighthouse/audits/http2).

result.name: no-old-flexbox
result.helpText: The 2009 spec of Flexbox is deprecated and is 2.3x slower than the latest spec. [Learn more](https://developers.google.com/web/tools/lighthouse/audits/old-flexbox).

result.name: uses-passive-event-listeners
result.description: Uses passive listeners to improve scrolling performance
result.helpText: Consider marking your touch and wheel event listeners as `passive` to improve your page's scroll performance. [Learn more](https://developers.google.com/web/tools/lighthouse/audits/passive-event-listeners).

result.name: no-mutation-events
result.description: Avoids Mutation Events in its own scripts
result.helpText: Mutation Events are deprecated and harm performance. Consider using Mutation Observers instead. [Learn more](https://developers.google.com/web/tools/lighthouse/audits/mutation-events).

result.name: no-document-write
result.helpText: For users on slow connections, external scripts dynamically injected via `document.write()` can delay page load by tens of seconds. [Learn more](https://developers.google.com/web/tools/lighthouse/audits/document-write).

result.debugString: Lighthouse was unable to determine the destination of some anchor tags. If they are not used as hyperlinks, consider removing the _blank target.
result.name: external-anchors-use-rel-noopener
result.helpText: Open new tabs using `rel="noopener"` to improve performance and prevent security vulnerabilities. [Learn more](https://developers.google.com/web/tools/lighthouse/audits/noopener).

result.name: geolocation-on-start
result.description: Avoids requesting the geolocation permission on page load
result.helpText: Users are mistrustful of or confused by sites that request their location without context. Consider tying the request to user gestures instead. [Learn more](https://developers.google.com/web/tools/lighthouse/audits/geolocation-on-load).

result.name: notification-on-start
result.description: Avoids requesting the notification permission on page load
result.helpText: Users are mistrustful of or confused by sites that request to send notifications without context. Consider tying the request to user gestures instead. [Learn more](https://developers.google.com/web/tools/lighthouse/audits/notifications-on-load).

value.label: line: 45
value.code: Calling Element.createShadowRoot() for an element which already hosts a shadow root is deprecated. See https://www.chromestatus.com/features/4668884095336448 for more details.
value.text: Calling Element.createShadowRoot() for an element which already hosts a shadow root is deprecated. See https://www.chromestatus.com/features/4668884095336448 for more details.

value.label: line: 291
value.code: Synchronous XMLHttpRequest on the main thread is deprecated because of its detrimental effects to the end user's experience. For more help, check https://xhr.spec.whatwg.org/.
value.text: Synchronous XMLHttpRequest on the main thread is deprecated because of its detrimental effects to the end user's experience. For more help, check https://xhr.spec.whatwg.org/.

value.label: line: 294
value.code: 'window.webkitStorageInfo' is deprecated. Please use 'navigator.webkitTemporaryStorage' or 'navigator.webkitPersistentStorage' instead.
value.text: 'window.webkitStorageInfo' is deprecated. Please use 'navigator.webkitTemporaryStorage' or 'navigator.webkitPersistentStorage' instead.

value.label: line: ???
value.code: /deep/ combinator is deprecated and will be a no-op in M60, around August 2017. See https://www.chromestatus.com/features/4964279606312960 for more details.
value.text: /deep/ combinator is deprecated and will be a no-op in M60, around August 2017. See https://www.chromestatus.com/features/4964279606312960 for more details.

result.name: deprecations
result.helpText: Deprecated APIs will eventually be removed from the browser. [Learn more](https://www.chromestatus.com/features#deprecated).

result.name: manifest-short-name-length
result.description: Manifest's `short_name` won't be truncated when displayed on homescreen
result.helpText: Make your app's `short_name` less than 12 characters to ensure that it's not truncated on homescreens. [Learn more](https://developers.google.com/web/tools/lighthouse/audits/manifest-short_name-is-not-truncated).

a11y-color-contrast.title: Color Contrast Is Satisfactory
a11y-color-contrast.description: Screen readers and other assitive technologies require annotations to understand otherwise ambiguous content.

a11y-describe-contents.title: Elements Describe Contents Well
a11y-describe-contents.description: Screen readers and other assitive technologies require annotations to understand otherwise ambiguous content.

a11y-well-structured.title: Elements Are Well Structured
a11y-well-structured.description: Screen readers and other assitive technologies require annotations to understand otherwise ambiguous content.

a11y-aria.title: ARIA Attributes Follow Best Practices
a11y-aria.description: Screen readers and other assitive technologies require annotations to understand otherwise ambiguous content.

a11y-correct-attributes.title: Elements Use Attributes Correctly
a11y-correct-attributes.description: Screen readers and other assitive technologies require annotations to understand otherwise ambiguous content.

a11y-element-names.title: Elements Have Discernable Names
a11y-element-names.description: Screen readers and other assitive technologies require annotations to understand otherwise ambiguous content.

a11y-language.title: Page Specifies Valid Language
a11y-language.description: Screen readers and other assitive technologies require annotations to understand otherwise ambiguous content.

a11y-meta.title: Meta Tags Used Properly
a11y-meta.description: Screen readers and other assitive technologies require annotations to understand otherwise ambiguous content.

aggregations.name: Progressive Web App
aggregations.description: These audits validate the aspects of a Progressive Web App. They are a subset of the [PWA Checklist](https://developers.google.com/web/progressive-web-apps/checklist).

score.name: Progressive Web App
score.description: These audits validate the aspects of a Progressive Web App. They are a subset of the [PWA Checklist](https://developers.google.com/web/progressive-web-apps/checklist).

subItems.name: service-worker
subItems.helpText: The service worker is the technology that enables your app to use many Progressive Web App features, such as offline, add to homescreen, and push notifications. [Learn more](https://developers.google.com/web/tools/lighthouse/audits/registered-service-worker).

subItems.name: works-offline
subItems.helpText: If you're building a Progressive Web App, consider using a service worker so that your app can work offline. [Learn more](https://developers.google.com/web/tools/lighthouse/audits/http-200-when-offline).

subItems.name: without-javascript
subItems.description: Contains some content when JavaScript is not available
subItems.helpText: Your app should display some content when JavaScript is disabled, even if it's just a warning to the user that JavaScript is required to use the app. [Learn more](https://developers.google.com/web/tools/lighthouse/audits/no-js).

subItems.name: is-on-https
subItems.helpText: All sites should be protected with HTTPS, even ones that don't handle sensitive data. HTTPS prevents intruders from tampering with or passively listening in on the communications between your app and your users, and is a prerequisite for HTTP/2 and many new web platform APIs. [Learn more](https://developers.google.com/web/tools/lighthouse/audits/https).

subItems.name: redirects-http
subItems.helpText: If you've already set up HTTPS, make sure that you redirect all HTTP traffic to HTTPS. [Learn more](https://developers.google.com/web/tools/lighthouse/audits/http-redirects-to-https).

subItems.name: load-fast-enough-for-pwa
subItems.description: Page load is fast enough on 3G
subItems.helpText: Satisfied if the _Time To Interactive_ duration is shorter than _10 seconds_, as defined by the [PWA Baseline Checklist](https://developers.google.com/web/progressive-web-apps/checklist). Network throttling is required (specifically: RTT latencies >= 150 RTT are expected).

subItems.debugString: Failures: No manifest was fetched, Site registers a Service Worker.
subItems.name: webapp-install-banner
subItems.description: User can be prompted to Install the Web App
subItems.helpText: While users can manually add your site to their homescreen, the [prompt (aka app install banner)](https://developers.google.com/web/fundamentals/engage-and-retain/app-install-banners/) will proactively prompt the user to install the app if the various requirements are met and the user has moderate engagement with your site.

subItems.name: splash-screen
subItems.description: Configured for a custom splash screen
subItems.helpText: A default splash screen will be constructed for your app, but satisfying these requirements guarantee a high-quality [splash screen](https://developers.google.com/web/updates/2015/10/splashscreen) that transitions the user from tapping the home screen icon to your app's first paint

subItems.debugString: Failures: No manifest was fetched, No `<meta name="theme-color">` tag found.
subItems.name: themed-omnibox
subItems.helpText: The browser address bar can be themed to match your site. A `theme-color` [meta tag](https://developers.google.com/web/updates/2014/11/Support-for-theme-color-in-Chrome-39-for-Android) will upgrade the address bar when a user browses the site, and the [manifest theme-color](https://developers.google.com/web/updates/2015/08/using-manifest-to-set-sitewide-theme-color) will apply the same theme site-wide once it's been added to homescreen.

subItems.name: viewport
subItems.description: Has a `<meta name="viewport">` tag with `width` or `initial-scale`
subItems.helpText: Add a viewport meta tag to optimize your app for mobile screens. [Learn more](https://developers.google.com/web/tools/lighthouse/audits/has-viewport-meta-tag).

subItems.name: content-width
subItems.description: Content is sized correctly for the viewport
subItems.helpText: If the width of your app's content doesn't match the width of the viewport, your app might not be optimized for mobile screens. [Learn more](https://developers.google.com/web/tools/lighthouse/audits/content-sized-correctly-for-viewport).

subItems.name: first-meaningful-paint
subItems.helpText: First meaningful paint measures when the primary content of a page is visible. [Learn more](https://developers.google.com/web/tools/lighthouse/audits/first-meaningful-paint).

subItems.name: speed-index-metric
subItems.helpText: Speed Index shows how quickly the contents of a page are visibly populated. [Learn more](https://developers.google.com/web/tools/lighthouse/audits/speed-index).

subItems.name: estimated-input-latency
subItems.helpText: The score above is an estimate of how long your app takes to respond to user input, in milliseconds. There is a 90% probability that a user encounters this amount of latency, or less. 10% of the time a user can expect additional latency. If your score is higher than Lighthouse's target score, users may perceive your app as laggy. [Learn more](https://developers.google.com/web/tools/lighthouse/audits/estimated-input-latency).

subItems.name: time-to-interactive
subItems.helpText: Time to Interactive identifies the time at which your app appears to be ready enough to interact with. [Learn more](https://developers.google.com/web/tools/lighthouse/audits/time-to-interactive).

subItems.name: link-blocking-first-paint
subItems.helpText: Link elements are blocking the first paint of your page. Consider inlining critical links and deferring non-critical ones. [Learn more](https://developers.google.com/web/tools/lighthouse/audits/blocking-resources).

subItems.name: script-blocking-first-paint
subItems.helpText: Script elements are blocking the first paint of your page. Consider inlining critical scripts and deferring non-critical ones. [Learn more](https://developers.google.com/web/tools/lighthouse/audits/blocking-resources).

subItems.name: uses-optimized-images
subItems.helpText: Images should be optimized to save network bytes. The following images could have smaller file sizes when compressed with [WebP](https://developers.google.com/speed/webp/) or JPEG at 80 quality. [Learn more about image optimization](https://developers.google.com/web/fundamentals/performance/optimizing-content-efficiency/image-optimization).

subItems.name: uses-request-compression
subItems.helpText: Text-based responses should be served with compression (gzip, deflate or brotli) to minimize total network bytes. [Learn more](https://developers.google.com/web/fundamentals/performance/optimizing-content-efficiency/optimize-encoding-and-transfer).

subItems.name: uses-responsive-images
subItems.helpText: Image sizes served should be based on the device display size to save network bytes. Learn more about [responsive images](https://developers.google.com/web/fundamentals/design-and-ui/media/images) and [client hints](https://developers.google.com/web/updates/2015/09/automating-resource-selection-with-client-hints).

subItems.name: total-byte-weight
subItems.helpText: Network transfer size [costs users real dollars](https://whatdoesmysitecost.com/) and is [highly correlated](http://httparchive.org/interesting.php#onLoad) with long load times. Try to find ways to reduce the size of required files.

subItems.name: dom-size
subItems.helpText: Browser engineers recommend pages contain fewer than ~1,500 DOM nodes. The sweet spot is a tree depth < 32 elements and fewer than 60 children/parent element. A large DOM can increase memory, cause longer [style calculations](https://developers.google.com/web/fundamentals/performance/rendering/reduce-the-scope-and-complexity-of-style-calculations), and produce costly [layout reflows](https://developers.google.com/speed/articles/reflow). [Learn more](https://developers.google.com/web/fundamentals/performance/rendering/).

subItems.name: critical-request-chains
subItems.helpText: The Critical Request Chains below show you what resources are required for first render of this page. Improve page load by reducing the length of chains, reducing the download size of resources, or deferring the download of unnecessary resources. [Learn more](https://developers.google.com/web/tools/lighthouse/audits/critical-request-chains).

subItems.name: user-timings
subItems.helpText: Consider instrumenting your app with the User Timing API to create custom, real-world measurements of key user experiences. [Learn more](https://developers.google.com/web/tools/lighthouse/audits/user-timing).

aggregations.name: Accessibility
aggregations.description: These checks highlight opportunities to [improve the accessibility of your app](https://developers.google.com/web/fundamentals/accessibility).

score.name: Accessibility
score.description: These checks highlight opportunities to [improve the accessibility of your app](https://developers.google.com/web/fundamentals/accessibility).

subItems.name: accesskeys
subItems.helpText: `accesskey` attributes allow the user to quickly activate or focus part of the page.Using the same `accesskey` more than once could lead to a confusing experience.

subItems.name: aria-allowed-attr
subItems.helpText: Each ARIA `role` supports a specific subset of `aria-*` attributes. Mismatching these invalidates the `aria-*` attributes. [Learn more](https://developers.google.com/web/tools/lighthouse/audits/aria-allowed-attributes).

subItems.name: aria-required-attr
subItems.helpText: Some ARIA roles have required attributes that describe the state of the element to screen readers. [Learn more](https://developers.google.com/web/tools/lighthouse/audits/required-aria-attributes).

subItems.name: aria-required-children
subItems.helpText: Some ARIA parent roles require specific roles on their children to perform their accessibility function.

subItems.name: aria-required-parent
subItems.description: `[role]`s are contained by their required parent element.
subItems.helpText: Some ARIA roles require specific roles on their parent element to perform their accessibility function.

subItems.name: aria-roles
subItems.helpText: ARIA roles require specific values to perform their accessibility function.

subItems.name: aria-valid-attr-value
subItems.helpText: Assistive technologies, like screen readers, can't interpret ARIA attributes with invalid values. [Learn more](https://developers.google.com/web/tools/lighthouse/audits/valid-aria-values).

subItems.name: aria-valid-attr
subItems.description: `[aria-*]` attributes are valid and not misspelled.
subItems.helpText: Assistive technologies, like screen readers, can't interpret ARIA attributes with invalid names. [Learn more](https://developers.google.com/web/tools/lighthouse/audits/valid-aria-attributes).

subItems.name: audio-caption
subItems.helpText: Captions convey information such as identifying who is speaking, dialogue, and non-speech information. This can help deaf or hearing impaired users access meaningful content.

subItems.name: button-name
subItems.helpText: An accessible name helps convey the purpose of a button. Without one, a screen reader will only announce the word "button".

subItems.name: bypass
subItems.description: The page contains a heading, skip link, or landmark region.
subItems.helpText: Adding ways to bypass repetitive content lets keyboard users navigate the page more efficiently.

value.description: Ensures the contrast between foreground and background colors meets WCAG 2 AA contrast ratio thresholds
value.help: Elements must have sufficient color contrast

any.message: Element has insufficient color contrast of 1.33 (foreground color: #ffc0cb, background color: #eeeeee, font size: 18.0pt, font weight: bold)

nodes.failureSummary:
Fix any of the following:
  Element has insufficient color contrast of 1.33 (foreground color: #ffc0cb, background color: #eeeeee, font size: 18.0pt, font weight: bold)

any.message: Element has insufficient color contrast of 1.33 (foreground color: #ffc0cb, background color: #eeeeee, font size: 12.0pt, font weight: normal)

nodes.failureSummary:
Fix any of the following:
  Element has insufficient color contrast of 1.33 (foreground color: #ffc0cb, background color: #eeeeee, font size: 12.0pt, font weight: normal)

subItems.name: color-contrast
subItems.description: Background and foreground colors have a sufficient contrast ratio.
subItems.helpText: Low-contrast text is difficult or impossible for many users to read. [Learn more](https://developers.google.com/web/tools/lighthouse/audits/contrast-ratio).

subItems.name: definition-list
subItems.description: `<dl>`'s contain only properly-ordered `<dt>` and `<dd>` groups, `<script>` or <template> elements.
subItems.helpText: When definition lists are not properly marked up screen readers may produce confusing or inaccurate output.

subItems.name: dlitem
subItems.description: Definition list items are wrapped in `<dl>` elements.
subItems.helpText: Definition list items (<dt> and/or <dd>) wrapped in parent <dl> elements enable screen readers to properly announce content.

subItems.name: document-title
subItems.helpText: Screen reader users use page titles to get an overview of the contents of the page.

subItems.name: duplicate-id
subItems.description: `[id]` attributes on the page are unique.
subItems.helpText: Unique `id=""` attributes help ensure assistive technologies do not overlook elements with the same id.

subItems.name: frame-title
subItems.helpText: Screen reader users rely on a frame title to describe the contents of the frame.

value.description: Ensures every HTML document has a lang attribute
value.help: <html> element must have a lang attribute

any.message: The <html> element does not have a lang attribute

nodes.failureSummary:
Fix any of the following:
  The <html> element does not have a lang attribute

subItems.name: html-has-lang
subItems.helpText: The `lang` attribute is useful for multilingual screen reader users who may prefer a language other than the default.

subItems.name: html-lang-valid
subItems.description: `<html>` element has a valid value for its `[lang]` attribute.
subItems.helpText: Specifying a valid [BCP 47 language](https://www.w3.org/International/questions/qa-choosing-language-tags#question) helps screen readers announce text properly.

subItems.name: image-alt
subItems.helpText: Informative elements should aim for short, descriptive alternate text. Decorative elements can be ignored with an empty alt attributes, e.g. [alt=""].[Learn more](https://developers.google.com/web/tools/lighthouse/audits/alt-attribute).

subItems.name: input-image-alt
subItems.helpText: When an image is being used as an `<input>` button, providing alternative text can help screen reader users understand the purpose of the button.

subItems.name: label
subItems.helpText: Labels ensure that form controls are announced properly by assistive technologies, like screen readers. [Learn more](https://developers.google.com/web/tools/lighthouse/audits/form-labels).

subItems.name: layout-table
subItems.description: Presentational `<table>` elements avoid using `<th>`, `<caption>` or the `[summary]` attribute.
subItems.helpText: The presence of `<th>`, `<caption>` or the `summary` attribute on a presentational table may produce a confusing experince for a screen reader user as these elements usually indicates a data table.

subItems.name: link-name
subItems.helpText: Link text (and alternate text for images, when used as links) that is discernible, not duplicated, and focusable improves the navigating experience for screen reader users.

subItems.name: list
subItems.description: Lists contain only `<li>` elements and script supporting elements (`<script>` and `<template>`).
subItems.helpText: Screen readers have a specific way of announcing lists. Ensuring proper list structure aides screen reader output.

subItems.name: listitem
subItems.description: List items (`<li>`) are contained within `<ul>` or `<ol>` parent elements.
subItems.helpText: Screen readers require list items (`<li>`) to be contained within a parent `<ul>` or `<ol>` to be announced properly

subItems.name: meta-refresh
subItems.description: The document does not use `<meta http-equiv="refresh">`.
subItems.helpText: Users do not expect a page to refresh automatically, and doing so will move focus back to the top of the page. This may create a frustrating or confusing experience

subItems.name: meta-viewport
subItems.description: `[user-scalable="no"]` is not used in the `<meta name="viewport">` element and the `[maximum-scale]` attribute is not less than 5.
subItems.helpText: Disabling zooming is problematic for users with low vision who rely on screen magnification to properly see the contents of a web page.

subItems.name: object-alt
subItems.helpText: Screen readers cannot translate non-text content. Adding alt text to `<object>` elements will help a screen reader convey the meaning to a user.

subItems.name: tabindex
subItems.description: No element has a `[tabindex]` value greater than 0.
subItems.helpText: A value greater than 0 implies an explicit navigation ordering. Although technically valid, this often creates frustrating experiences for users who rely on assistive technologies. [Learn more](https://developers.google.com/web/tools/lighthouse/audits/tabindex).

subItems.name: td-headers-attr
subItems.description: Cells in a `<table>` element that use the `[headers]` attribute only refer to other cells of that same table.
subItems.helpText: Screen readers have features to make navigating tables easier. Ensuring `<td>` cells using the `[headers]` attribute only refer to other cells in the same table may improve the experience for screen reader users.

subItems.name: th-has-data-cells
subItems.description: `<th>` elements and elements with `[role="columnheader"/"rowheader"]` have data cells they describe.
subItems.helpText: Screen readers have features to make navigating tables easier. Ensuring table headers always refer to some set of cells may improve the experience for screen reader users.

subItems.name: valid-lang
subItems.helpText: Specifying a valid [BCP 47 language](https://www.w3.org/International/questions/qa-choosing-language-tags#question) on elements helps ensure that text is pronounced correctly by a screen reader.

subItems.name: video-caption
subItems.helpText: When a video provides a caption it is easier for deaf and hearing impaired users to access its information.

subItems.name: video-description
subItems.helpText: Audio descriptions provide relevant information for videos that dialogue cannot, such as facial expressions and scenes.

aggregations.name: Best Practices
aggregations.description: We've compiled some recommendations for modernizing your web app and avoiding performance pitfalls. These audits do not affect your score but are worth a look.

score.name: Best Practices
score.description: We've compiled some recommendations for modernizing your web app and avoiding performance pitfalls. These audits do not affect your score but are worth a look.

subItems.name: appcache-manifest
subItems.helpText: Application Cache has been [deprecated](https://html.spec.whatwg.org/multipage/browsers.html#offline) by [Service Workers](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/Service_Worker_API/Using_Service_Workers). Consider implementing an offline solution using the [Cache Storage API](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/Cache).

subItems.name: no-websql
subItems.helpText: Web SQL is deprecated. Consider using IndexedDB instead. [Learn more](https://developers.google.com/web/tools/lighthouse/audits/web-sql).

subItems.name: is-on-https
subItems.helpText: All sites should be protected with HTTPS, even ones that don't handle sensitive data. HTTPS prevents intruders from tampering with or passively listening in on the communications between your app and your users, and is a prerequisite for HTTP/2 and many new web platform APIs. [Learn more](https://developers.google.com/web/tools/lighthouse/audits/https).

subItems.displayValue: 12 requests were not handled over h2
subItems.name: uses-http2
subItems.description: Uses HTTP/2 for its own resources
subItems.helpText: HTTP/2 offers many benefits over HTTP/1.1, including binary headers, multiplexing, and server push. [Learn more](https://developers.google.com/web/tools/lighthouse/audits/http2).

subItems.name: no-old-flexbox
subItems.helpText: The 2009 spec of Flexbox is deprecated and is 2.3x slower than the latest spec. [Learn more](https://developers.google.com/web/tools/lighthouse/audits/old-flexbox).

subItems.name: uses-passive-event-listeners
subItems.description: Uses passive listeners to improve scrolling performance
subItems.helpText: Consider marking your touch and wheel event listeners as `passive` to improve your page's scroll performance. [Learn more](https://developers.google.com/web/tools/lighthouse/audits/passive-event-listeners).

subItems.name: no-mutation-events
subItems.description: Avoids Mutation Events in its own scripts
subItems.helpText: Mutation Events are deprecated and harm performance. Consider using Mutation Observers instead. [Learn more](https://developers.google.com/web/tools/lighthouse/audits/mutation-events).

subItems.name: no-document-write
subItems.helpText: For users on slow connections, external scripts dynamically injected via `document.write()` can delay page load by tens of seconds. [Learn more](https://developers.google.com/web/tools/lighthouse/audits/document-write).

subItems.debugString: Lighthouse was unable to determine the destination of some anchor tags. If they are not used as hyperlinks, consider removing the _blank target.
subItems.name: external-anchors-use-rel-noopener
subItems.helpText: Open new tabs using `rel="noopener"` to improve performance and prevent security vulnerabilities. [Learn more](https://developers.google.com/web/tools/lighthouse/audits/noopener).

subItems.name: geolocation-on-start
subItems.description: Avoids requesting the geolocation permission on page load
subItems.helpText: Users are mistrustful of or confused by sites that request their location without context. Consider tying the request to user gestures instead. [Learn more](https://developers.google.com/web/tools/lighthouse/audits/geolocation-on-load).

subItems.name: notification-on-start
subItems.description: Avoids requesting the notification permission on page load
subItems.helpText: Users are mistrustful of or confused by sites that request to send notifications without context. Consider tying the request to user gestures instead. [Learn more](https://developers.google.com/web/tools/lighthouse/audits/notifications-on-load).

value.label: line: 45
value.code: Calling Element.createShadowRoot() for an element which already hosts a shadow root is deprecated. See https://www.chromestatus.com/features/4668884095336448 for more details.
value.text: Calling Element.createShadowRoot() for an element which already hosts a shadow root is deprecated. See https://www.chromestatus.com/features/4668884095336448 for more details.

value.label: line: 291
value.code: Synchronous XMLHttpRequest on the main thread is deprecated because of its detrimental effects to the end user's experience. For more help, check https://xhr.spec.whatwg.org/.
value.text: Synchronous XMLHttpRequest on the main thread is deprecated because of its detrimental effects to the end user's experience. For more help, check https://xhr.spec.whatwg.org/.

value.label: line: 294
value.code: 'window.webkitStorageInfo' is deprecated. Please use 'navigator.webkitTemporaryStorage' or 'navigator.webkitPersistentStorage' instead.
value.text: 'window.webkitStorageInfo' is deprecated. Please use 'navigator.webkitTemporaryStorage' or 'navigator.webkitPersistentStorage' instead.

value.label: line: ???
value.code: /deep/ combinator is deprecated and will be a no-op in M60, around August 2017. See https://www.chromestatus.com/features/4964279606312960 for more details.
value.text: /deep/ combinator is deprecated and will be a no-op in M60, around August 2017. See https://www.chromestatus.com/features/4964279606312960 for more details.

subItems.name: deprecations
subItems.helpText: Deprecated APIs will eventually be removed from the browser. [Learn more](https://www.chromestatus.com/features#deprecated).

subItems.name: manifest-short-name-length
subItems.description: Manifest's `short_name` won't be truncated when displayed on homescreen
subItems.helpText: Make your app's `short_name` less than 12 characters to ensure that it's not truncated on homescreens. [Learn more](https://developers.google.com/web/tools/lighthouse/audits/manifest-short_name-is-not-truncated).
